title: 2 Corinthians Chapter 3 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 2 Corinthians chapter 3 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 2 Corinthians Chapter 3 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 2 Corinthians Chapter 3.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 3:2, what are the Corinthians described as?
options: Our epistle written in our hearts
questions.correctAnswer: Our epistle written in our hearts
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 3:2 states that the Corinthians are our epistle written in our hearts, known and read of all men.

questions.question: What is written not with ink but with the Spirit of the living God, according to 2 Corinthians 3:3?
options: The epistle of Christ ministered by us
questions.correctAnswer: The epistle of Christ ministered by us
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 3:3 describes the epistle of Christ ministered by Paul and his companions as written not with ink but with the Spirit of the living God.

questions.question: What gives life according to 2 Corinthians 3:6?
questions.correctAnswer: The spirit
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 3:6 says that the letter killeth, but the spirit giveth life.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 3:7, what was glorious but to be done away?
options: The ministration of death written in stones
questions.correctAnswer: The ministration of death written in stones
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 3:7 describes the ministration of death, written and engraved in stones, as glorious but that glory was to be done away.

questions.question: What does 2 Corinthians 3:8 say about the ministration of the spirit?
options: It is the same as the letter
questions.correctAnswer: It is rather glorious
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 3:8 asks how the ministration of the spirit shall not be rather glorious, implying it surpasses the former glory.

questions.question: True or False: 2 Corinthians 3:11 says that what remains is more glorious than what is done away.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 3:11 states that if what was done away was glorious, much more that which remaineth is glorious.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 3:12, what do the writers use because of their hope?
questions.correctAnswer: Great plainness of speech
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 3:12 says that seeing they have such hope, they use great plainness of speech.

questions.question: What did Moses put over his face, according to 2 Corinthians 3:13?
questions.correctAnswer: A vail
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 3:13 states that Moses put a vail over his face so the children of Israel could not steadfastly look to the end of what was abolished.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 3:14, what remains until this day in the reading of the old testament?
questions.correctAnswer: The same vail untaken away
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 3:14 explains that the minds of the people were blinded because the same vail remains untaken away in the reading of the old testament.

questions.question: True or False: 2 Corinthians 3:15 says that when Moses is read, the vail is upon their heart.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 3:15 clearly states that even unto this day, when Moses is read, the vail is upon their heart.

questions.question: What happens when it shall turn to the Lord, according to 2 Corinthians 3:16?
options: The vail shall be taken away
questions.correctAnswer: The vail shall be taken away
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 3:16 states that when it shall turn to the Lord, the vail shall be taken away.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from 2 Corinthians 3:17: 'Now the Lord is that ______: and where the Spirit of the Lord is, there is liberty.'
questions.correctAnswer: Spirit
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 3:17 says 'Now the Lord is that Spirit: and where the Spirit of the Lord is, there is liberty.'

questions.question: What does 2 Corinthians 3:18 say happens to those who behold with open face the glory of the Lord?
options: They are changed into the same image from glory to glory
They are blinded by a vail
They become ministers of the letter
questions.correctAnswer: They are changed into the same image from glory to glory
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 3:18 says that we all, beholding as in a glass the glory of the Lord, are changed into the same image from glory to glory.

questions.question: True or False: 2 Corinthians 3:5 says that our sufficiency is of ourselves.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 3:5 clearly states that we are not sufficient of ourselves but our sufficiency is of God.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 3:1, what question is asked about commending themselves?
options: Do we begin again to commend ourselves?
Do we write letters to the children of Israel?
Should we put a vail over our faces?
Are tables of stone still needed?
questions.correctAnswer: Do we begin again to commend ourselves?
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 3:1 opens with the question, 'Do we begin again to commend ourselves?'

medium.title: 2 Corinthians Chapter 3 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 2 Corinthians Chapter 3 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with feelings of inadequacy in ministry. Based on 2 Corinthians 3, what biblical truth would you share about where our sufficiency comes from?
options: Our sufficiency comes from personal effort
Our sufficiency depends on approval from others
Our sufficiency is due to human wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: Our sufficiency is of God
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 3:5 teaches that we are not sufficient of ourselves, but our sufficiency is from God, reminding believers that confidence and ability in ministry come from Him, not self-effort.

questions.question: How does 2 Corinthians 3 describe the way believers are like an epistle of Christ?
options: Written with the Spirit of the living God on fleshy tables of the heart
Written by human wisdom in scrolls
questions.correctAnswer: Written with the Spirit of the living God on fleshy tables of the heart
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 3:3 explains believers are the epistle of Christ ministered by the apostles, written not with ink but with the Spirit of the living God on hearts, emphasizing transformation by the Spirit.

questions.question: A believer feels burdened by the law and guilt. Based on 2 Corinthians 3, what hope can you share about the ministry of the Spirit in contrast to the ministry of the letter?
options: The spirit gives life while the letter kills
The letter brings freedom while the spirit condemns
Both the letter and spirit equally bring condemnation
The letter gives life but the spirit brings death
questions.correctAnswer: The spirit gives life while the letter kills
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 3:6 contrasts the ministry of the letter, which kills, with the ministry of the Spirit, which gives life, encouraging believers to find hope and liberty in the Spirit's work rather than legalistic condemnation.

questions.question: In dealing with pride, how does 2 Corinthians 3 teach us about the source of our confidence?
options: Our confidence is through Christ to God-ward
Our confidence is in our own achievements
Our confidence depends on human approval
We should not have any confidence
questions.correctAnswer: Our confidence is through Christ to God-ward
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 3:4 reveals that the apostles had confidence through Christ toward God, teaching believers to rely on Christ for assurance rather than self or others.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 3, how does the glory of the new covenant compare to the glory of the old covenant?
options: The new covenant's glory exceeds the old
The old covenant's glory is greater
questions.correctAnswer: The new covenant's glory exceeds the old
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 3:9-10 explains the ministration of righteousness (new covenant) exceeds in glory the ministration of condemnation (old covenant), highlighting the superior glory of grace over law.

questions.question: How does 2 Corinthians 3 encourage believers to speak about spiritual matters given the hope they have?
questions.correctAnswer: With great plainness of speech
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 3:12 states that seeing such hope, believers should use great plainness of speech, encouraging clear and bold communication of the gospel and spiritual truths.

questions.question: What does 2 Corinthians 3 say about the veil Moses put over his face and its significance today?
options: The veil symbolizes blindness of heart which remains until turning to the Lord
The veil is a permanent barrier that cannot be removed
The veil was only for decoration
questions.correctAnswer: The veil symbolizes blindness of heart which remains until turning to the Lord
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 3:13-14 explains Moses put a veil over his face so Israel could not see the end of what was abolished; this veil remains on their hearts until they turn to the Lord, illustrating spiritual blindness removed by Christ.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged by spiritual bondage. According to 2 Corinthians 3, what truth about the Spirit and liberty can you share?
options: Where the Spirit of the Lord is, there is liberty
The Spirit brings bondage and fear
Liberty is unrelated to the Spirit
questions.correctAnswer: Where the Spirit of the Lord is, there is liberty
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 3:17 clearly states that the Lord is the Spirit and where His Spirit is, there is liberty, assuring believers of freedom through the Holy Spirit.

questions.question: How does 2 Corinthians 3 teach us about spiritual transformation in the life of a believer?
options: Believers are changed into the same image from glory to glory by the Spirit
Believers remain unchanged regardless of faith
Transformation happens by human willpower alone
Transformation is temporary and not lasting
questions.correctAnswer: Believers are changed into the same image from glory to glory by the Spirit
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 3:18 teaches that all believers, with unveiled faces, behold the glory of the Lord and are transformed into His image by the Spirit, showing progressive sanctification through the Spirit's work.

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Corinthians 3, the ministration of death written on stones had no glory at all.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 3:7 mentions the ministration of death written on stones was glorious, but this glory was temporary and would be done away with, indicating it did have glory but was surpassed by the new covenant.

questions.question: True or False: The veil that blinded the minds of Israel is permanently in place and cannot be removed according to 2 Corinthians 3.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 3:16 states that when one turns to the Lord, the veil is taken away, showing it is not permanent but removed by turning to Christ.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 2 Corinthians 3 teaches that the new covenant is ministered not of the _______, but of the spirit, for the letter killeth, but the spirit giveth life.
questions.correctAnswer: letter
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 3:6 explains the new covenant ministry is not of the letter but of the spirit, contrasting the lifelessness of the letter with the life-giving power of the Spirit.

questions.question: A believer is hesitant to share their faith openly. What does 2 Corinthians 3 encourage about speaking with hope?
questions.correctAnswer: Use great plainness of speech
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 3:12 encourages believers to speak boldly and plainly because of the hope they have, promoting openness in sharing the gospel.

questions.question: How does 2 Corinthians 3 describe the transformation process for believers?
options: Changed into the same image from glory to glory by the Spirit of the Lord
Changed only by human effort and discipline
questions.correctAnswer: Changed into the same image from glory to glory by the Spirit of the Lord
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 3:18 describes believers being transformed progressively by the Spirit into Christ’s image, highlighting the Spirit's role in sanctification.

questions.question: What does 2 Corinthians 3 say about the glory that was made glorious but had no glory in comparison?
options: Its glory was exceeded by the glory that excelleth
It was the greatest glory ever
questions.correctAnswer: Its glory was exceeded by the glory that excelleth
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 3:10 explains that even the glory of the old covenant, though glorious, had no glory compared to the surpassing glory of the new covenant.

hard.title: 2 Corinthians Chapter 3 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 2 Corinthians Chapter 3.

questions.question: What metaphor does Paul use to describe the Corinthians in 2 Corinthians 3:2-3?
options: An epistle written in hearts, not with ink but with the Spirit of God
A temple made of living stones
A city set on a hill
questions.correctAnswer: An epistle written in hearts, not with ink but with the Spirit of God
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 3:2-3 describe the Corinthians as an epistle of Christ ministered by Paul, written not with ink but with the Spirit of the living God on fleshy tables of the heart.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 3:6, what is the contrast between the 'letter' and the 'spirit' in the new testament ministry?
options: The letter kills, but the spirit gives life
The letter gives life, but the spirit condemns
The letter is obsolete, but the spirit is temporary
The letter is glorious, but the spirit is shameful
questions.correctAnswer: The letter kills, but the spirit gives life
questions.explanation: Verse 6 explicitly contrasts the letter that kills with the spirit that gives life, highlighting the vitality of the Spirit's ministry.

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 3:7-8, Paul compares the ministration of death to what other ministration?
questions.correctAnswer: The ministration of the spirit
questions.explanation: Paul contrasts the ministration of death written on stones with the far more glorious ministration of the spirit (3:7-8).

questions.question: How does Paul explain the fading glory of Moses' face in 2 Corinthians 3:7?
options: The glory was to be done away
It was a sign of Israel's disobedience
It was caused by Moses’ humility
questions.correctAnswer: The glory was to be done away
questions.explanation: Verse 7 states that the glory on Moses' face was temporary and destined to be done away.

questions.question: What reason does Paul give in 2 Corinthians 3:11 for the greater glory of the new covenant compared to the old?
options: Because what remains is far more glorious
Because the old covenant was flawed
Because the new covenant has more laws
Because the old covenant was written in stone
questions.correctAnswer: Because what remains is far more glorious
questions.explanation: Paul explains in verse 11 that if the old covenant glory was temporary, the new covenant's glory is greater because it remains eternally.

questions.question: What literary device is Paul using in 2 Corinthians 3:12 when he says 'we use great plainness of speech' compared to Moses who used a veil?
questions.correctAnswer: Contrast
questions.explanation: Paul contrasts his openness with Moses’ veiling, highlighting the difference in revelation and understanding (3:12-13).

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 3:14-15, what causes the 'veil' to remain on the minds and hearts of those reading the old testament?
options: Their minds are blinded until turning to Christ
questions.correctAnswer: Their minds are blinded until turning to Christ
questions.explanation: Paul states in verses 14-15 that the veil remains because their minds are blinded until they turn to the Lord.

questions.question: What happens 'when it shall turn to the Lord' according to 2 Corinthians 3:16?
options: The veil shall be taken away
They become ministers of the letter
questions.correctAnswer: The veil shall be taken away
questions.explanation: Verse 16 promises that turning to the Lord removes the veil from the heart, allowing true understanding.

questions.question: Who is identified as 'that Spirit' in 2 Corinthians 3:17, and what is present where this Spirit is?
questions.correctAnswer: The Lord; there is liberty
questions.explanation: Verse 17 identifies the Lord as the Spirit and states that where the Spirit of the Lord is, there is liberty.

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 3:18, believers are described as being transformed 'from glory to glory' by what means?
options: By the Spirit of the Lord
questions.correctAnswer: By the Spirit of the Lord
questions.explanation: Verse 18 states that believers are transformed into the Lord's image by the Spirit of the Lord, progressing from glory to glory.

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Corinthians 3:5, Paul claims that his sufficiency comes from his own strength.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 5 says Paul is not sufficient in himself, but his sufficiency is from God.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'fleshy tables of the heart' in 2 Corinthians 3:3 as opposed to 'tables of stone'?
options: It signifies a spiritual transformation rather than a written code
It refers to a physical heart transplant
It indicates a new legal document
It symbolizes the permanence of the law
questions.correctAnswer: It signifies a spiritual transformation rather than a written code
questions.explanation: Verse 3 contrasts the old covenant written on stone tablets with the new covenant written on hearts by the Spirit, signifying internal spiritual change.

questions.question: How does 2 Corinthians 3:9 develop the theme of ministration by comparing condemnation and righteousness?
options: Condemnation is more glorious than righteousness
Both condemnation and righteousness have equal glory
Righteousness is obsolete compared to condemnation
questions.correctAnswer: Righteousness exceeds condemnation in glory
questions.explanation: Verse 9 states that if condemnation had glory, righteousness has much more exceeding glory, emphasizing the superiority of righteousness.

questions.question: Which Old Testament figure is alluded to in 2 Corinthians 3:7-13 to illustrate the fading glory and veiling of the old covenant?
questions.correctAnswer: Moses
questions.explanation: Paul references Moses’ veiled face and glory in verses 7-13 to contrast the fading old covenant with the new covenant’s glory.

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Corinthians 3:17, liberty is a result of the presence of the Spirit of the Lord.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 17 explicitly states that where the Spirit of the Lord is, there is liberty.

theological.title: 2 Corinthians Chapter 3 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 2 Corinthians Chapter 3 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 3:3, how are believers described in relation to the epistle of Christ?
options: Written not with ink but with the Spirit of the living God
Written by the hands of apostles
questions.correctAnswer: Written not with ink but with the Spirit of the living God
questions.explanation: Verse 3 explains believers are the epistle of Christ written not with ink but with the Spirit of the living God on fleshy tables of the heart, indicating the internal and spiritual nature of God's work in salvation. This corresponds with Ezekiel 36:26-27, Jeremiah 31:33, Hebrews 8:10, and Romans 2:29, all emphasizing God's work writing His law in the heart by the Spirit.

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 3:6, what contrast does Paul make between 'the letter' and 'the spirit'?
options: The letter kills, but the spirit gives life
The letter gives life, but the spirit kills
Both the letter and the spirit give life
Both the letter and the spirit kill
questions.correctAnswer: The letter kills, but the spirit gives life
questions.explanation: Verse 6 states that the new testament ministry is of the spirit, not of the letter, for the letter kills but the spirit gives life. This reflects Old Testament law versus New Testament grace and life through the Spirit (John 6:63, Romans 7:6, Galatians 3:2-3, Ezekiel 37:14).

questions.question: What does Paul claim about the ministration of death written on stones in 2 Corinthians 3:7?
options: It was glorious but its glory was to be done away
It was more glorious than the ministration of the Spirit
questions.correctAnswer: It was glorious but its glory was to be done away
questions.explanation: Verse 7 acknowledges the ministration of death (the Mosaic Law) was glorious, so much so that Moses' face shone, but that glory was temporary and to be done away. This correlates with Exodus 34:29-35, Hebrews 8:13, and Galatians 3:24-25, showing the temporary nature of the old covenant glory.

questions.question: How does Paul describe the ministration of the Spirit compared to the ministration of death in 2 Corinthians 3:8?
options: The ministration of the Spirit is more glorious
The ministration of the Spirit is less glorious
The ministration of the Spirit is identical
questions.correctAnswer: The ministration of the Spirit is more glorious
questions.explanation: Verse 8 contrasts the ministration of death with the ministration of the Spirit, stating the latter is more glorious. This highlights the superiority of gospel ministry over the Mosaic Law (Romans 8:2, John 16:13-14, Hebrews 7:22-25).

questions.question: What reason does Paul give in 2 Corinthians 3:9 for the ministration of righteousness exceeding in glory the ministration of condemnation?
options: Because righteousness brings life and condemnation brings death
Because righteousness is written on stone tablets
questions.correctAnswer: Because righteousness brings life and condemnation brings death
questions.explanation: Verse 9 states if condemnation (Law) had glory, then righteousness (gospel) exceeds in glory much more, emphasizing the life-giving nature of righteousness (Romans 5:17, Isaiah 54:17, John 1:17, Galatians 5:22-23).

questions.question: What does Paul say about the glory of the old covenant compared to the new covenant in 2 Corinthians 3:10-11?
options: The new covenant has a surpassing and remaining glory
The old covenant has a permanent glory
The new covenant has less glory
questions.correctAnswer: The new covenant has a surpassing and remaining glory
questions.explanation: Verses 10-11 emphasize that although the old covenant was glorious, its glory was surpassed by the new covenant's glory which remains. This aligns with Hebrews 8:6-13 and Jeremiah 31:31-34 about the new covenant's superiority.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 3:12, how do Paul and his companions speak because of the hope they have?
options: They use great plainness of speech
questions.correctAnswer: They use great plainness of speech
questions.explanation: Verse 12 states that because of their hope, Paul and his companions speak with great plainness, implying transparency and boldness in proclaiming the gospel (Acts 4:29, Ephesians 6:19, 2 Timothy 1:8).

questions.question: What does Paul say Moses did with his face in 2 Corinthians 3:13, and what was its purpose?
options: He put a veil over his face so Israel could not steadfastly look to the end of what was abolished
He uncovered his face to show God's glory
He painted his face to symbolize judgment
He wore a crown to show authority
questions.correctAnswer: He put a veil over his face so Israel could not steadfastly look to the end of what was abolished
questions.explanation: Verse 13 explains Moses put a veil over his face to prevent Israel from looking steadfastly at the fading glory of the old covenant, symbolizing the temporary nature of the Law (Exodus 34:33-35, Hebrews 10:1).

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 3:14, why are the minds of the Israelites described as blinded?
options: Because the veil remains upon their hearts in the reading of the Old Testament
Because they do not have the law
Because they do not believe in Moses
questions.correctAnswer: Because the veil remains upon their hearts in the reading of the Old Testament
questions.explanation: Verse 14 states their minds are blinded because the veil remains unlifted when reading the Old Testament, preventing full spiritual understanding. This is consistent with Isaiah 6:9-10, Matthew 13:14-15, and John 12:40.

questions.question: What happens to the veil when one turns to the Lord according to 2 Corinthians 3:16?
options: The veil shall be taken away
questions.correctAnswer: The veil shall be taken away
questions.explanation: Verse 16 promises that when a person turns to the Lord, the veil is removed, enabling spiritual understanding. This aligns with John 3:3-6, 2 Corinthians 4:6, and Ephesians 1:17-18.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 3:17, where there is the Spirit of the Lord, what is present?
questions.correctAnswer: There is liberty
questions.explanation: Verse 17 states the Lord is the Spirit and where the Spirit of the Lord is, there is liberty, signifying freedom from sin and condemnation (John 8:32-36, Romans 8:1-2, Galatians 5:1).

questions.question: How are believers transformed according to 2 Corinthians 3:18?
options: By beholding the glory of the Lord with unveiled faces, being changed into the same image
By following the letter of the Law only
questions.correctAnswer: By beholding the glory of the Lord with unveiled faces, being changed into the same image
questions.explanation: Verse 18 says believers, with open faces beholding the glory of the Lord as in a mirror, are transformed into His image by the Spirit, reflecting progressive sanctification (Psalm 17:15, Romans 8:29, 1 John 3:2, Philippians 3:21).

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 3:1-2, Paul refers to the Corinthians as what kind of epistle?
options: An epistle written in our hearts, known and read of all men
An epistle written with ink and pen
questions.correctAnswer: An epistle written in our hearts, known and read of all men
questions.explanation: Verses 1-2 describe the Corinthians as a living letter written in Paul's heart and known by all men, indicating their transformed lives are a testimony to the gospel (Philippians 1:7, Colossians 1:1-2, 1 Thessalonians 2:13).

questions.question: What does Paul affirm about his sufficiency in 2 Corinthians 3:5?
options: Our sufficiency is from God, not from ourselves
We are sufficient by our own strength
Our sufficiency comes from human wisdom
We are not sufficient at all
questions.correctAnswer: Our sufficiency is from God, not from ourselves
questions.explanation: Verse 5 clarifies Paul’s adequacy comes from God, not self, highlighting divine empowerment for ministry (2 Timothy 3:5, Philippians 4:13, Ephesians 3:7, John 15:5).

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 3:4, through whom does Paul have such confidence toward God?
questions.correctAnswer: Through Christ
questions.explanation: Verse 4 states Paul’s confidence before God is through Christ, emphasizing Christ as the mediator and source of assurance (Hebrews 4:14-16, Romans 8:34, 1 Timothy 2:5).
